Literature Review: Candida auris has emerged as a significant global health threat since its first identification in 2009, rapidly spreading across continents and causing severe infections with high mortality rates. This literature review aims to explore the genetic factors contributing to C. auris' emergence, its genome organization, and the mechanisms underlying its multidrug resistance.The sudden emergence of C. auris has puzzled researchers, leading to various hypotheses about its origins. Chow et al. (2020) proposed that climate change might have played a role in the simultaneous emergence of genetically distinct C. auris clades across different geographical regions. They suggested that rising global temperatures could have allowed C. auris to adapt to the human body temperature, facilitating its transition from an environmental fungus to a human pathogen.Genomic studies have revealed that C. auris possesses a compact genome of approximately 12.5 Mb, with a high degree of genetic diversity among different clades (Muñoz et al., 2018). This genetic diversity suggests that C. auris may have existed for a long time before its clinical emergence, potentially adapting to various environmental niches. Interestingly, Lockhart et al. (2017) identified four major clades of C. auris, each associated with a specific geographical region, indicating that the species might have emerged independently in multiple locations.One of the most concerning aspects of C. auris is its inherent resistance to multiple antifungal drugs. Kean et al. (2018) demonstrated that C. auris exhibits high levels of resistance to fluconazole, a commonly used azole antifungal. They found that this resistance is primarily mediated by mutations in the ERG11 gene, which encodes the target enzyme of azoles. Additionally, Rybak et al. (2019) identified increased expression of efflux pump genes, such as CDR1 and MDR1, contributing to azole resistance in C. auris.Resistance to amphotericin B, another crucial antifungal agent, has also been observed in C. auris. Escandón et al. (2019) reported that mutations in the ERG3 gene, involved in ergosterol biosynthesis, could confer amphotericin B resistance. This finding highlights the adaptability of C. auris in developing resistance mechanisms against different classes of antifungals.Echinocandin resistance, although less common, has been documented in C. auris isolates. Kordalewska et al. (2018) identified mutations in the FKS1 gene, which encodes the target of echinocandins, in resistant isolates. The emergence of echinocandin resistance is particularly concerning, as these drugs are often considered the last line of defense against multidrug-resistant Candida species.The cell wall of C. auris plays a crucial role in its pathogenicity and drug resistance. Zamith-Miranda et al. (2019) found that C. auris possesses a thicker cell wall compared to other Candida species, which may contribute to its increased resistance to antifungal drugs and environmental stressors. Furthermore, they observed alterations in cell wall composition, including increased chitin content, which could enhance the fungus's ability to evade host immune responses.MAP kinase signaling pathways have been implicated in the stress response and virulence of C. auris. Day et al. (2018) demonstrated that the HOG1 MAP kinase pathway is involved in osmotic stress tolerance and antifungal resistance in C. auris. They found that deletion of the HOG1 gene resulted in increased susceptibility to various stressors and antifungal drugs, suggesting that this pathway could be a potential target for novel therapeutic approaches.The rapid spread of C. auris in healthcare settings has been attributed to its ability to form biofilms and persist on surfaces. Sherry et al. (2017) showed that C. auris isolates could form robust biofilms on various medical devices and surfaces, contributing to its persistence in hospital environments. This biofilm formation ability, coupled with its resistance to common disinfectants, makes C. auris particularly challenging to eradicate from healthcare facilities.Understanding the genetic factors contributing to C. auris' emergence and drug resistance is crucial for developing effective control strategies. Chowdhary et al. (2019) emphasized the need for improved surveillance and diagnostic methods to detect and monitor C. auris infections accurately. They also highlighted the importance of implementing strict infection control measures in healthcare settings to prevent the spread of this pathogen.In conclusion, the emergence of Candida auris as a multidrug-resistant fungal pathogen poses a significant challenge to global public health. Its genetic diversity, adaptability, and multiple drug resistance mechanisms make it a formidable threat. Future research should focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying its virulence and drug resistance, as well as developing novel therapeutic approaches to combat this emerging pathogen effectively.
